newsitem.title: USA: US Plains cattle trade quiet after sales -feedlots.
newsitem.headline: US Plains cattle trade quiet after sales -feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets were quiet early Thursday, with most of this week's showlists close to being sold out, feedlot sources said.
"We have no bids, no offers and no cattle left to sell," a Texas Panhandle area feedlot manager said.
Most cattle left on showlists after two weeks of brisk packer buying are mostly likely light-weight animals, a Kansas cattle feeder said.
"There's not many 1,200 lb cattle left out there this week," he said.
Any sales Thursday would be thin, sources said.
The bulk of this week's sales were done at $69.00 per cwt on Tuesday, although there were a few sold Monday at $68.00.
At $69.00, owners probably earned about $60.00 to $70.00 per head, a Kansas source said.
Fed cattle prices the past two weeks were buoyed by strong beef demand as retailers reportedly booked beef to be featured in Memorial Day holiday advertising features, sources said.
Lower beef prices on Wednesday suggested that the holiday buying could be starting to wind down, they said.
Beef prices Wednesday were quoted down $0.74 to $1.10 per cwt on 280 fabricated loads sold, USDA reported.
